The relation between valutative operations and subsets of ${\rm Zar}(D)$ exhibits a si\-mi\-lar behaviour to the relation between spectral operations and subsets of ${\rm Spec}(D)$.  Similarly to the prime spectrum case (see the paragraph preceding Proposition \ref{spettrali}),  for each subset $Y$ of the Riemann-Zariski space ${\rm Zar}(D)$, we set $Y^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}}:= \{z \in {\rm Zar}(D) \mid y \in {\operatorname{\mbox{\rm\texttt{Cl}}}(\{z\}) \mbox{ for some } y \in Y \}$ and we denote $\mbox{\rm{\texttt{Cl}}}^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{inv}}}}}}}(Y)$ the closure of $Y$ in the inverse topology of  the spectral space ${\rm Zar}(D)$  (see \cite{ dofo-86}, \cite[Proposition 8]{ho}  and \cite{fifolo2, FiSp}).
Compare the next lemma with Proposition \ref{spettrali}.


\begin{lemma}\label{zar-inv}
	 Let $D$ be an integral domain and let $Y$ and $Z$ be two nonempty subsets of $\mbox{\rm{\rm Zar}}(D)$.
	Then, the following statements hold. 
	\begin{enumerate}[\rm(1)]
		\item $\wedge_Y=\wedge_Z$ if and only if $Y^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}}=Z^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}}$.

		\item $\wedge_Y$ is of finite type if and only if $Y$ is quasi-compact.

		\item $(\wedge_Y)_{\!{_f}}=(\wedge_Z)_{\!{_f}}$ if and only if 
		 $\mbox{\rm{\texttt{Cl}}}^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{inv}}}}}}}(Y)=
		 \mbox{\rm{\texttt{Cl}}}^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{inv}}}}}}}(Z)$.
		 \item $(\wedge_Y)_{\!{_f}}= \wedge_{\mbox{\rm\footnotesize{\texttt{Cl}}}^{\mbox{\rm\tiny{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{inv}}}}}}}(Y)}$. 
	\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
(1) Note that, in the present situation,  $Y^{{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}} = \{ÊV \in \mbox{\rm{\rm Zar}}(D) \mid V \supseteq V_0, $ for some $V_0 \in Y \}$.
Assume first that $\wedge_Y=\wedge_Z$. Let $V$ be a valuation domain such that $V\in Y^{{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}\setminus Z^{{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}$. 
Then, for any $W\in Z$, we can pick an element $x_W\in W\setminus V$. 
It follows that $I:=(x_W^{-1} \mid W\in Z)\subseteq M_V$, where $M_V$ is the maximal ideal of $V$. 
Thus, if $V_0\in Y$ is such that $V_0\subseteq V$ (such a $V_0$ exists since $V\in Y^{{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}$),
 we have $I V_0\subseteq M_{V_0}$ and, in particular, 
$1\notin I^{\wedge_Y}$. 
On the other hand, clearly $1\in I^{\wedge_Z}$, a contradiction. The converse it is straightforward since, for each $Y \subseteq 
\mbox{\rm{\rm Zar}}(D)$, $\wedge_Y = \wedge_{Y^{{\mbox{\tiny{\texttt{{gen}}}}}}}$. 

For (2), (3) and (4), see respectively \cite[Proposition 4.5]{FiSp}, \cite[Theorem 4.9]{fifolo2} and, \cite[Corollary 4.17]{fifolo2}.
\end{proof}
